Sellside seeing this as a victory for shareholders. Peel Hunt's Jonathan Pritchard -- whose Sports Direct reinvention note from a week or two ago is highly recommended -- says .......

BE

In another twist to the Sports Direct tale, CEO Dave Forsey has
resigned, to be replaced by Mike Ashley. We are sorry to see Mr
Forsey go: he tried very hard to build bridges with the City and
will be missed. Clearly the issues surrounding accountability and
working practices have caused an internal shakeout and the calls
for Mike Ashley to have a more executive role have been
answered. Analysts’ meetings will undoubtedly now be all ticket.
The management change is interesting but ultimately the shares
will succeed or fail on the implementation of the new strategy.
Moving away from “pile it high, sell it cheap” and becoming
more respectful of third-party brand equity will take time and
cultural change but it’s the only way. Forecast momentum is still
negative but signs that Sports Direct’s own brand equity is
stabilising would make the shares very interesting. BUY.

BE

Dave Forsey, Mike’s right arm, has resigned. Dave has been with Sports
Direct pretty much from the start (and for all of his career). He has been the main
point of contact for analysts throughout SPD’s quoted life and tried hard to build
bridges with the City. His focus from an internal perspective was more on the
operational side and, therefore, in the aftermath of him foregoing his bonus, it is
not an enormous surprise that he is moving on. After all, it seemed unlikely that
the press and the unions would be sated until they had their pound of flesh over
the working practices issues. Mike Ashley takes over as CEO: shareholders were
calling for more executive responsibility and here it is. He has promoted two of
his lieutenants: Karen Byers (familiar to the City and well regarded internally and
externally) becomes global head of operations and Sean Nevitt (less well known
to us) is now global head of commercial. Neither Karen nor Mike are known for
flowery and evasive approaches, so analysts meetings should be highly
entertaining and informative from now on. We do, however, as Dave leaves, hope
that his efforts to create a rapport with both buy and sell side are continued and
management does not just pay lip service to IR.

11:15 am
BE

Strategic change afoot. There were two “did he really just say that?” moments
at the AGM: Mike Ashley denounced “pile it high sell it cheap” as no longer an
appropriate stance. He also stated that Sports Direct would now be more
respectful of third-party brand equity. Our view is that the big brands, such as
Nike and adidas, have downgraded the product file that Sports Direct has
received in response to the low retail standards (the opposite is true as JD).
Customers have voted with their feet and Sports Direct must now sing to the
manufacturers’ tune in order to get back in their good books. That means
demonstrating that it can showcase product attractively and, in order to show
that, Sports Direct will open around 12 flagship stores every year. That will be
expensive but it is the only way. If Sports Direct is able to persuade the brands to
provide it with better product, then trading will doubtless improve, especially if it
is in tandem with better retail (and working) practices. It will take time, but this
mind-set for change and not denial is crucial to the shares, which look very
interesting.

PM

Analysts’ meetings will undoubtedly now be all ticket. -- too right

BE

Indivior PLC (INDV:LSE): Last: 280.70, down 45.5 (-13.95%), High: 310.00, Low: 269.30, Volume: 2.88m

11:21 am
BE

The conduct of Indivior (owned by Reckitt at the time, of course) "forced consumers to pay more for Suboxone and severely limited their options for treating their opioid addictions,” says Pennsylvania Attorney General Bruce Beemer.

BE

Accuses Indivior of "a range of anticompetitive conduct" when patents started expiring in 2008.

BE

This is very much a known risk. Suboxone film was by anyone's definition an exceptionally cynical product that looked entirely like patent extension.

11:24 am
BE

Sellside, therefore, saying "yeah, this is bad. But you invested in a single-product skag dealer, you really should've known the bad stuff already.")

BE

Sellside, therefore, saying "yeah, this is bad. But you invested in a single-product skag dealer, you really should've known the bad stuff already."

BE

Here's RBC.

11:25 am
BE

New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman and 35 other attorney generals are suing Indivior for anti-competitive practices, this relates to the Product Hopping case, which we have highlighted as a potential risk previously and now appears to be gathering pace. We believe this has been off the radar for many investors (many focusing on the depot and generic ANDA litigation) so this could impact the shares today, especially as it
coincides with recent backlash against Spec Pharma companies on pricing and selling practices, etc. (company put through a small, 5% price rise only this year) and as we have the run in to the US election. We have no view on size of any potential fine should Indivior lose the case, but to put it in perspective the company has benefited from extra protection on the Film for 7 years so far – we estimate that equates to c.$+5bn and counting in accrued revenues over the period on the Film itself. Generic tablets launched in 2013, and so counting just the period before the generic tabs launched and when Indivior (then Reckitts) launched its Film equates to we think c.$1-2bn, but the Film had already captured c70% of the market and not many have ever switched back (non-substitutable products). We believe this case will not involve prior parent company Reckitts, as we understand that the legal risk was passed on to Indivior when the company was spun out of Reckitts, absolving itself of all potential fines

BE

Along with a handy ticklist from the Attorney General website .....

BE

l

l
l
l
l
The lawsuit alleges the company switched to a dissolvable film strip to prevent other companies from providing a generic form of the pill.
First, to thwart the entry of a generic version of Suboxone, Indivior informed the FDA in 2007 that it planned to introduce a new sublingual film (a dissolvable oral
strip), version of Suboxone. Because the film version of Suboxone would not be the pharmaceu cal equivalent of the tablet form, pharmacists would not be able to
substitute a generic manufacturer’s tablet version for the film version. If Indivior could introduce a film version of Suboxone and convince doctors and patients to
switch to the film, they could prevent loss of sales to the generic tablet.
At the time, FDA officials were skeptical of this argument but ordered the manufacturer and any generic manufacturers to participate in a shared Risk Evaluation and
Mitigation Strategy. Indivior then asked the FDA to delay approving a generic until it could be proven there was no risk to children. This was all in a way to delay
approval of generic versions of the drug, according to the lawsuit.
The FDA denied this petition and approved generic versions in 2012. By then, according to the lawsuit, Indivior had already gotten out of the pill market and switched
to manufacturing the strips.
"My office will not permit drug companies to engage in antic-competitive conduct that unlawfully extends their monopolies - and their monopoly profits - on drugs,"
Schneiderman said in a statement. "We will take decisive action against drug companies that engage in schemes to manipulate the cost and availability of treatment
options to maximize corporate profits. Opioid abuse is a public health crisis, and opioid-dependent patients should have access to the most affordable addiction
treatment options available."

11:26 am
BE

The lawsuit alleges the company switched to a dissolvable film strip to prevent other companies from providing a generic form of the pill.
First, to thwart the entry of a generic version of Suboxone, Indivior informed the FDA in 2007 that it planned to introduce a new sublingual film (a dissolvable oral
strip), version of Suboxone. Because the film version of Suboxone would not be the pharmaceu cal equivalent of the tablet form, pharmacists would not be able to
substitute a generic manufacturer’s tablet version for the film version. If Indivior could introduce a film version of Suboxone and convince doctors and patients to
switch to the film, they could prevent loss of sales to the generic tablet.
At the time, FDA officials were skeptical of this argument but ordered the manufacturer and any generic manufacturers to participate in a shared Risk Evaluation and
Mitigation Strategy. Indivior then asked the FDA to delay approving a generic until it could be proven there was no risk to children. This was all in a way to delay
approval of generic versions of the drug, according to the lawsuit.
The FDA denied this petition and approved generic versions in 2012. By then, according to the lawsuit, Indivior had already gotten out of the pill market and switched
to manufacturing the strips.
"My office will not permit drug companies to engage in antic-competitive conduct that unlawfully extends their monopolies - and their monopoly profits - on drugs,"
Schneiderman said in a statement. "We will take decisive action against drug companies that engage in schemes to manipulate the cost and availability of treatment
options to maximize corporate profits. Opioid abuse is a public health crisis, and opioid-dependent patients should have access to the most affordable addiction
treatment options available."

BE

Deutsche also.

BE

ndivior has confirmed 35 US states and the District of Columbia have filed a
Lawsuit against the company alleging that it tried to keep generic Suboxone
tablets off the market back in 2009 when its patent expired. As a reminder
Indivior launched its flagship product Suboxone film in 2010 and was
successful in switching the market prior to generics to the tablet formulation
launching in 2013. Whilst fresh headlines are emerging today, we understand
this is part of an already ongoing FTC (Federal Trade Commission) investigation
which launched in June 2013. We expect this to be a negative on sentiment
this morning. However, in reality this investigation is likely to rumble on for
many years and any outcome would then be subject to appeal. We see the
most likely outcome as a fine but acknowledge it remains very difficult to
quantify at this stage. In Indivior’s favour is the fact that Suboxone film does
offer a number of advantages of the tablet formulation and opioid addiction is
in significant focus in the US at present therefore we would not expect
anything that would cause significant financial harm to the company. We also
highlight there was a similar investigation in France where Indivior was fined
only EUR318k. We reiterate our Buy as we continue to see sources of upside
from business development, continued outperformance of Suboxone film as
well as ultimate approval of its monthly injection of Suboxone (buprenorphine),
RBP-6000, in 2017.

11:26 am
BE

Indivior has confirmed 35 US states and the District of Columbia have filed a
Lawsuit against the company alleging that it tried to keep generic Suboxone
tablets off the market back in 2009 when its patent expired. As a reminder
Indivior launched its flagship product Suboxone film in 2010 and was
successful in switching the market prior to generics to the tablet formulation
launching in 2013. Whilst fresh headlines are emerging today, we understand
this is part of an already ongoing FTC (Federal Trade Commission) investigation
which launched in June 2013. We expect this to be a negative on sentiment
this morning. However, in reality this investigation is likely to rumble on for
many years and any outcome would then be subject to appeal. We see the
most likely outcome as a fine but acknowledge it remains very difficult to

from business development, continued outperformance of Suboxone film as
well as ultimate approval of its monthly injection of Suboxone (buprenorphine),
RBP-6000, in 2017.

BE

A lot of the argument with Indivior is how much its customers -- who are demographically interesting, I think it's fair to say -- just want the brand Suboxone because they know it works.

So anyway, Nesis (the CEO not the brother) was at the Denver gold thing the other week. Here's what he said.

BE




Low cost production with substantial growth on the horizon as the company looks to grow to 1.8Moz gold equivalent by
2020. At this point, ~90% of production would be gold.
Accretive transactions continue with Komar and Kapan being able to drive forward more production at lower costs through
synergistic benefits post-acquisition.
Growth continues to progress as Kyzyl moves forward and Nezhda and new Viksha PGM progress towards feasibility
study. Nezhda's majority open pit and high grade ore body could provide ~10 Moz. The Viksha PGM project, with today's
initial resource estimate containing 4.2 Moz Pd, 1.4 Moz PT, 0.9 Moz of gold and 220kt of copper has exploration upside,
making this a compelling long-term bulk tonnage project. Decisions on both will occur in 2018.

undefined
11:42 am
BE

While on miners, Liberum saying sell into the recent rally.

BE

China's supply-side coal bump is all very nice but it doesn't mean things are improving any over there.

BE

Sentiment around the mining sector has hit new highs in the past three weeks. The main driver has been a re-acceleration of a number of data points in August, namely house prices (here), fixed asset investment (here), electricity production and building completions. In conjunction with spot coking coal (here) and thermal coal prices (here) hitting new highs, FCF generation on spot has lifted above 10% of all the majors.

11:43 am
BE

So ..............

BE

he extent to which house price growth encourages property new starts and also stimulates consumption via the wealth effect will be crucial for the direction of the mining sector in the next six months. Whilst the acceleration of headline numbers in August do give comfort that the current wave of demand from the Q1 fiscal pump has further to run, we still don't think the data paints an entirely rosy picture. Property prices are rising aggressively in Tier 1 and 2 cities, however transaction volumes and new starts remain weak in Tier 3-5 cities, which represent 70% of new start volumes. Based on the current trajectory we believe new starts in Tier 3-5 cities could be printing negative YoY numbers by next month.

We believe this has implications for both copper and iron ore demand, the latter of which is also facing pressure from accelerating supply in the months ahead. We remain underweight the mining sector.

BE

The extent to which house price growth encourages property new starts and also stimulates consumption via the wealth effect will be crucial for the direction of the mining sector in the next six months. Whilst the acceleration of headline numbers in August do give comfort that the current wave of demand from the Q1 fiscal pump has further to run, we still don't think the data paints an entirely rosy picture. Property prices are rising aggressively in Tier 1 and 2 cities, however transaction volumes and new starts remain weak in Tier 3-5 cities, which represent 70% of new start volumes. Based on the current trajectory we believe new starts in Tier 3-5 cities could be printing negative YoY numbers by next month.

We believe this has implications for both copper and iron ore demand, the latter of which is also facing pressure from accelerating supply in the months ahead. We remain underweight the mining sector.

11:44 am
BE

Data from August re-confirmed a further acceleration in house prices accross all cities, and also an increase in transaction volumes. However, by breaking the data down into Tiers, we can see that whilst the recovery has spread to Tier 2 cities it is still anaemic in Tier 3-5 cities.

We combine the CREIS (China Real Estate Index) data with the NBS data to manufacture Tier by Tier transaction and new starts data - this involves an assumption around similar levels of starts relative to populations being seen in unreported Tier 2 cities. The first point to note is that Tier 3-5 cities are still the main driver of commodity demand, representing 71% of floor space newly started in China.

BE

Whilst growth in new starts in Tier 1 and 2 cities has been on a tear this year, in Tier 3-5 cities, the anaemic house price growth has seen a fairly muted recovery in new starts which did not bounce in August along with other Chinese data.

BE

Want to see that graph? It's a nice one.

11:45 am
BE

BE

(I'd like to know if the people living in a Tier 5 cities know about that classification.)

BE

Looking ahead, increased measures to cool property price appreciation could have an impact on starts in Tier 1 and 2 cities in the short-term. In addition, comps around new starts do get tougher in September (new starts were +15% YoY in Sep'15 and +41% vs. the August print), but then ease off until Q1 next year.

In our minds, the extent to which new starts in Tier 3-5 cities respond to the moderate price growth seen so far this year (+2% YoY), will be crucial to sector performance. At this stage, we don't think the weak (and fading) response of new starts in Tier 3-5 cities warrants an upgrade, with risks to demand still prevalent.

BE

(@Mouselet: yeah, seems nothing happened. It's not uncommon when companies talk to lots of parties about potential disposals, those talks sprawl into other areas. But it seems quite rare that those talks come to anything.)

BE

What else then? I'm not really keen to do much with this Fingerprint Cards theory.

BE

Which you can read yourself here: http://betaville.c...fingerprint-cards/

11:52 am
BE

I only note is because Haitong gives the idea a runthrough this morning.

BE

According to Betaville, Beijing Watertek Information Technology (300324: CN) has been in talks with Fingerprint Cards (FINGB: SS) for a potential acquisition. We believe there could be interest from Chinese bidders for Fingerprint Cards, as the mobile phone industry expects the penetration of fingerprint recognition in the Chinese smartphone market to grow from 20% in 2015 to 45% in 2016, and therefore the business opportunity is significant. However, we do not see a strong strategic argument for Beijing Watertek Information Technology (an enterprise software vendor) to acquire Fingerprint Cards. We note that Beijing Watertek Information Technology’s market capitalization is a mere $3bn (vs. $4.1bn for Fingerprint Cards) and net cash is a mere $60m. Hence, we think that Beijing Watertek Information Technology is perhaps just a member of a consortium that could potentially pursue an acquisition.

BE

Market sizing: China accounts for approx. 1/3 of the 1.46bn unit global smartphone market (2016E according to IDC.) The supply chain expects the penetration of fingerprint recognition in China to increase from less than 20% of smartphones shipped in 2015 to 40-50% in 2016. This translates to ~220 million units of fingerprint recognition equipped smartphones for the year (if taken at the mid-point).

Competition: Fingerprint Cards historically has 90% of the market share in China, but this looks at risk of being competed away by Chinese/Taiwanese IC design houses working with algorithm providers. We think Goodix (603160: CN, 24% owned by MediaTek) is the biggest competitor to Fingerprint Card. According to Digitimes, the ASP of a fingerprint recognition module has dropped from $10 to $3 over the past 12 months, indicating increased competitive pressures.

Supply Chain: We note that Fingerprint Card has been outsourcing its manufacturing to China, with SMIC (0981: HK) as its foundry partner and O-Film (002456: CN) as one of its biggest direct clients.

Beijing Watertek Information Technology: Founded in 1997, the company is known as a software solution and service provider. In 2015, tax related software and devices (mainly invoice issuers) accounted for 65% of its revenue. Beijing Watertek Information Technology also offers IC card solutions to the energy industry (mainly petrol stations) and this could potentially be the business where Beijing Watertek Information Technology sees the value of fingerprint recognition technology for mobile payment usage. It is worth mentioning that Beijing Watertek Information Technology provides equipment testing services to the Chinese military, which may cause any acquisition of a European based company to come under increased regulatory scrutiny. We note that the proposed Chinese acquisition of fellow Nordic technology company, Opera Software, was not approved by the deadline and had to be restructured as a smaller transaction.

11:55 am
PM

With Brexit newsflow picking up and, we think, risks tilting towards a hard exit, we believe the sweet spot for UK mid-caps is coming to an end. We look for opportunities for investors to turn more cautious on UK mid-caps from a Macro and Micro perspective.

PM

The sweet-spot for UK mid-caps is coming to an end. The surprising resilience in UK macro data post referendum and the decline in political uncertainty over the summer has seen the FTSE 250 rally by 22% off the post-Brexit lows. While our economists no longer forecast a UK recession, they still anticipate protracted headwinds to the UK economy. With news flow regarding Brexit negotiations increasing, and the risks tilting towards a hard exit, in our economists' view, we look for opportunities for investors to turn more cautious on UK mid-caps in three ways:

PM

1) Long FTSE 100 vs Short FTSE 250. Five reasons for this trade: 1) the FTSE 250 is 2.3 times as exposed to UK revenues as the FTSE 100; 2) the FTSE 100 trades at an 18% discount to the long-run average relative DY to the FTSE 250; 3) our FX strategists see GBPUSD declining to 1.24 in 3Q16, which would favour the FTSE 100; 4) EPS is likely at a structural trough for large versus mid-caps; and 5) underperformance from cyclicals would likely hurt the FTSE 250.

2) Sell our UK domestic exposure basket (MSSTUKDO). The basket’s relative performance has closely tracked sterling, where we expect further weakness, and relative earnings revisions remain at an all-time low. Underweight-rated names in the basket are: United Utilities, Hargreaves Lansdown, Morrison, Intu Properties, Derwent London, Capital & Counties, Great Portland Estates, Shaftesbury, Clydesdale, Dunelm Group, Pets at Home Group, Londonmetric Property, Halfords, JD Wetherspoon, Enterprise Inns and Capita.

3) Underweight-rated UK mid-caps. We include a list of 33 Underweight-rated UK stocks with a market cap below £10bn. With input from our analysts, we highlight 8 Underweight ideas from this list: Morrison, Kingfisher, Royal Mail, Synthomer, Dixons Carphone, Clydesdale, Capital & Counties and William Hill.

BE

Highest growth on the lowest multiple – upgrade to Buy Jimmy Choo offers the highest estimated earnings growth within luxury (25% EPS
CAGR), yet the stock trades on 13.5x our 2017E PE, 30% discount to peers. We have
greater confidence in the group’s LFL recovery in H2, as initiatives in the challenging US
market are bearing fruit – confirmed by management at our Global Consumer
Conference. Margin expansion should therefore accelerate in H2 placing it firmly back on
track to reach its mid-term targets as the group unlocks its growth opportunities.
Upgrade to Buy with an increased PO of GBp150, implying 25% upside potential.

BE

Accelerating earnings growth yet depressed valuation
Jimmy Choo has de-rated by 25% YTD due to an uncertain environment and low liquidity
in the shares. However we have confidence that earnings downgrades have bottomed
and the group will deliver the highest 3-year EPS CAGR (25%) in the sector. A positive
LFL recovery from 2H will be driven by improving performance in the US and strong
tourism in the UK (11% of sales). Also benefiting from FX, this should accelerate margin
expansion in H2. We see 9-14% upside to 2016-18E EPS consensus.

BE

One of the few growth stories in luxury
We think that Jimmy Choo offers an attractive long-term growth profile relative to peers,
as it benefits from channel, regional and product opportunities. The brand still has scope
to increase its directly operated store network by at least 30% primarily driven by Asia and
to penetrate men’s shoes. We forecast 120bps of EBIT margin expansion over 2016-20E
as the group benefits from increasing retail mix, scale and operating leverage. There is 7%
incremental upside to our 2020E EPS if mid-term targets are reached by then.

strength of the brand in our view. The brand has a leading digital presence according to
our Brand Leading Indicator, which we believe is important in sustaining brand
desirability, and accordingly LFL growth.
